description: Malagasy President Andry Rajoelina announced on Sunday, March 22, 2020, that the country's two main cities, Antananarivo and Toamasina, will be locked down from Monday, March 23, to prevent further spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19). All individuals are required to stay at home and all transport, except for goods, will be prohibited. Only essential businesses, such as food stores and banks, will be allowed to remain open, and only one person per family will be allowed to shop.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

On April 5, 2020, authorities announced that lockdown measures currently in place in the capital Antananarivo and Toamasina will be extended for two weeks. The city of Fianarantsoa will also introduce lockdown measures for this period. 
 UPDATE: On April 5, 2020, lockdown was extended for the regions of Analamanga (Antananarivo), Antsinanana (Toamasina) and Haute Matsiatra (Fianarantsoa), until April 19. UPDATE: On April 20, 2020, Malagasy President Andry Rajoelina began easing lockdown measures in the cities of Antananarivo, Toamasina and Fianarantsoa. description: On June 15, 2020, the government of Madagascar announced that all districts and regions of Madagascar were to resume all activities, except for 5 areas (the district of Toamasina I and II, Fénérive-Est, Moramanga, and the Analamanga region).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of July 6, 2020, total lockdown measures were reintroduced in the Analamanga region for a period of 15 days, until July 20. Under these restrictions, only one person per household may leave their homes between 06:00 and 12:00 (local time).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From 19 April, 2021, the Analamanga region was put under total lockdown on Saturdays and Sundays.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
From 19 April, 2021, the Analamanga region was put under total lockdown on Saturdays and Sundays.
 UPDATE: On 19 April 2021, the Analamanga region was put under total lockdown on Saturdays and Sundays. UPDATE: On 30 May 2021, the president of the Republic of Madagascar lifted the weekend lockdown.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 23, March, 2020, the Government of Madagascar opened the Covid-19 Centre Opérationnel de Commandement (Command Operational Centre) to coordinate the various policy measures implemented in response to Covid-19.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Madagascar, as of March 26, 2020, confinement measures have been put in place in order to curb the communal spread of COVID-19. Everyone has been asked to stay inside except in emergency situations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Madagascar, as of April 5, 2020, stay-at-home measures continue indefinitely. Everyone has been asked to stay inside except in emergency situations.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From October 23, 2021, Madagascar authorities announced the reopening of its borders to travellers. There’s mandatory PCR test on arrival and quarantine for one or two days pending results. In the event of a positive result, a 14-day confinement will be put in place, at the expense of the traveler.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Madagascar, as of March 23, 2020, only shops selling basic goods will remain open: supermarkets, grocery stores, and neighborhood markets. Their hours of operation are limited to between 6 a.m. to 12 p.m.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Madagascar, as of March 23, 2020, only shops selling basic goods will remain open: supermarkets, grocery stores, and neighborhood markets (open between 6 a.m. to 12 p.m). description: In Madagascar, as of April 5, 2020, all schools, churches, and all public spaces (bars, restaurants, shops, karaokes, etc.) will remain closed until April 19th. description: On June 27, 2021, Prime Minister of Madagascar Christian Ntsay announced that gathering of more than 400 people are prohibited, especially in the six districts where the virus is still actively circulating: Antananarivo-Renivohitra, Antananarivo Avaradrano, Antananarivo Atsimondrano, Ambohidratrimo, Ambatondrazaka and Fianarantsoa 1.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Antananarivo-Renivohitra (Analamanga); Antananarivo Avaradrano (Analamanga); Antananarivo Atsimondrano (Analamanga);  Ambohidratrimo (Analamanga); Ambatondrazaka (Alaotra-Mangoro); Fianarantsoa 1 (Haute Matsiatra)

description: In Madagascar, as of April 10, 2020, everyone must wear a face mask (or scarf that covers one's mouth and nose) while in the capital of Antananarivo. Anyone caught outside without a mask on will be detained by the police.
